tua_batch_name: Adjudicator Nick Adams HLTR source task 867 article number 100059 project 185
target_text: Research on the psychological toll of social distancing during epidemics is limited

tua_batch_name: Adjudicator Nick Adams HLTR source task 867 article number 100059 project 185
target_text: Researchers evaluated 24 studies looking at the psychological outcomes of people who were quarantined, an extreme form of social distancing, during outbreaks of SARS, H1N1 flu, Ebola and other infectious diseases since the early 2000s

tua_batch_name: Adjudicator Nick Adams HLTR source task 867 article number 100059 project 185
target_text: Many\xa0quarantined individuals experienced both short- and long-term mental health problems, including stress, insomnia, emotional exhaustion and substance abuse. For instance, one study compared quarantined versus non-quarantined individuals during an equine influenza outbreak. Of 2,760 quarantined people, 34 percent, or 938 individuals, reported high levels of psychological distress, which can indicate mental health problems such as anxiety and depression, during the outbreak compared with 12 percent of non-quarantined individuals

tua_batch_name: Adjudicator Nick Adams HLTR source task 867 article number 100059 project 185
target_text: Social distancing comes with psychological fallout
